head.title: Hydrogen Sensors Based on MoS2 Hollow Architectures Assembled by Pickering Emulsion | ACS Nano

meta.content: Hydrogen Sensors Based on MoS2 Hollow Architectures Assembled by Pickering Emulsion

For rapid hydrogen gas (H2) sensing, we propose the facile synthesis of the hollow structure of Pt-decorated molybdenum disulfide (h-MoS2/Pt) using ultrathin (mono- or few-layer) two-dimensional nanosheets. The controlled amphiphilic nature of MoS2 surface produces ultrathin MoS2 NS-covered polystyrene particles via one-step Pickering emulsification. The incorporation of Pt nanoparticles (NPs) on the MoS2, followed by pyrolysis, generates the highly porous h-MoS2/Pt. This hollow hybrid structure produces sufficiently permeable pathways for H2 and maximizes the active sites of MoS2, while the Pt NPs on the hollow MoS2 induce catalytic H2 spillover during H2 sensing. The h-MoS2/Pt-based chemiresistors show sensitive H2 sensing performances with fast sensing speed (response, 8.1 s for 1% of H2 and 2.7 s for 4%; and recovery, 16.0 s for both 1% and 4% H2 at room temperature in the air). These results mark the highest H2 sensing speed among 2D material-based H2 sensors operated at room temperature in air. Our fabrication method of h-MoS2/Pt structure through Pickering emulsion provides a versatile platform applicable to various 2D material-based hollow structures and facilitates their use in other applications involving surface reactions.

SUBJECTS:

div.p:
For rapid hydrogen gas (H
2
) sensing, we propose the facile synthesis of the hollow structure of Pt-decorated molybdenum disulfide (h-MoS
2
/Pt) using ultrathin (mono- or few-layer) two-dimensional nanosheets. The controlled amphiphilic nature of MoS
2
surface produces ultrathin MoS
2
NS-covered polystyrene particles
via
one-step Pickering emulsification. The incorporation of Pt nanoparticles (NPs) on the MoS
2
, followed by pyrolysis, generates the highly porous h-MoS
2
/Pt. This hollow hybrid structure produces sufficiently permeable pathways for H
2
and maximizes the active sites of MoS
2
, while the Pt NPs on the hollow MoS
2
induce catalytic H
2
spillover during H
2
sensing. The h-MoS
2
/Pt-based chemiresistors show sensitive H
2
sensing performances with fast sensing speed (response, 8.1 s for 1% of H
2
and 2.7 s for 4%; and recovery, 16.0 s for both 1% and 4% H
2
at room temperature in the air). These results mark the highest H
2
sensing speed among 2D material-based H
2
sensors operated at room temperature in air. Our fabrication method of h-MoS
2
/Pt structure through Pickering emulsion provides a versatile platform applicable to various 2D material-based hollow structures and facilitates their use in other applications involving surface reactions.

div.span: KEYWORDS:

div.div:
Hydrogen (H
2
) is one of the most promising next-generation energy sources because of its abundance in nature as well as high efficiency in energy combustion with eco-friendly byproducts (water, H
2
O).
(1)
However, since H
2
can be explosive (lower flammability limit is 4% of H
2
), it is very important to detect any leakage of H
2
. For example, the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) has set the target metrics of H
2
detection, including sensitivity (25% of relative resistance at 1% of H
2
), limit of detection (LOD, <0.1%), response speed (
t
90
< 1 s at H
2
1%) and recovery speed (
t
10
< 60 s), and cost (<$40/unit).
(2)
Up until now, there have been significant advances in H
2
sensors through the development of sensing materials.
(3)
Recently, metal hybrid plasmonic sensors have demonstrated fast H
2
detection (
t
90
< 1 s at H
2
4%).
(4,5)
While their response speeds were extremely fast in pure H
2
, their performances were delayed in air with a presence of interference of other gases (
i.e.
, O
2
). On account of the importance of excellent sensitivity and simple fabrication, various chemiresistors have been successfully developed for rapid sensing of H
2
.
(6,7)
The current state-of-the-art H
2
sensors are based on mild temperature operating palladium (Pd)-based chemiresistors that can detect H
2
with fast response and high selectivity.
(8â13)
The reaction between H
2
and Pd generates palladium hydride (PdH
x
), which enables the easy detection of H
2
by monitoring the resistances of Pd-based sensors.

Heterostructures of metal onto semiconductors with large surface-to-volume ratios have been developed to overcome the limitation of conventional sensing materials such as metal oxide and carbon-based electrodes.
(7,14)
In particular, two-dimensional (2D) transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs),
e.g.
, molybdenum disulfide (MoS
2
), are promising scaffold materials due to their affinity to H atom,
(15)
large surface area,
(16)
and tunable electrical- and chemical properties.
(17â21)
In this respect, 2D TMD-based composites have been investigated to build chemiresistors for the detection of nitrogen dioxides (NO
2
)
(22â24)
and ammonia (NH
3
)
(25â27)
but there are only a few reports demonstrating 2D TMD-based H
2
sensors.
(28â30)
The incorporation of Pd nanoparticles (NPs) on MoS
2
endows the composites with H
2
sensing properties,
(28)
but they showed limited response/recovery speeds (
t
90
and
t
10
> 10 min at H
2
1%). Importantly, with regard to the practical implementation of 2D TMD-based materials into devices, the severe aggregation and self-stacking of the TMDs as a result of van der Waals interaction decrease the gas permeability and access to active sites.
(16,31)
In this regard, several methods, such as the use of porous supports,
(22)
growth of TMDs on other active materials,
(32,33)
and introduction of hierarchical and hollow structures,
(34,35)
have been suggested to alleviate the aggregation of ultrathin 2D TMDs. However, the practical use of these methods is often limited because of the low yield and high processing cost. Thus, in order to acquire efficient H
2
sensors with scalable production, the development of a simple and reproducible synthetic method for building a 2D TMD-based structure having high sensing performance is desired.

Herein, we report the development of Pt NP-decorated ultrathin MoS
2
hollow spheres (h-MoS
2
/Pt) for rapid H
2
sensing. Our method is a simple two-step procedure: (i) generation of MoS
2
/Pt covered polystyrene (PS) colloidal particles, followed by (ii) heat treatment to produce h-MoS
2
/Pt by decomposition of the PS support (
Figure
1
). The amphiphilic MoS
2
sheets are designed to achieve the one-pot formation of MoS
2
@PS shell/core through Pickering emulsification. After the removal of the PS core, the resulting hollow structured h-MoS
2
/Pt has high free volume and surface area in a densely packed solid state. Then, the Pt NPs on h-MoS
2
enables chemiresistive H
2
sensing performance of MoS
2
by spillover effect. Thus, the h-MoS
2
/Pt sensors display H
2
sensing performance that
t
90
is 8.1 s for H
2
1% and 2.7 s for H
2
4%, and
t
10
is 16.0 s for both H
2
1% and 4% at room temperature in air. Furthermore, we investigate the chemiresistive sensing mechanism of h-MoS
2
/Pt by performing (1) the calculation of activation energy for H
2
reactions and (2)
in situ
Raman analysis during the H
2
sensing. Consequently, we demonstrate that the synergistic contributions of both the hollow MoS
2
structure and stable Pt NPs are crucial for the outstanding H
2
sensing performance of h-MoS
2
/Pt.

div.p:
Figure 1. Schematic illustration of the synthesis of Pt NPs-decorated hollow ultrathin MoS
2
(h-MoS
2
/Pt)
via
Pickering emulsification. (a)Â Fabrication of Pickering emulsion using ultrathin MoS
2
NSs. (b) Preparation of h-MoS
2
/Pt using the photoreduction of Pt precursors and the postheat treatment. (c) 3D structure of h-MoS
2
/Pt-based H
2
sensor.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Our strategy to develop hollow MoS
2
structures was based on the following considerations. First, we targeted the positioning of MoS
2
nanosheets (NSs) at the immiscible oil/water (O/W) interface in order to achieve a one-step fabrication of a MoS
2
shell through Pickering emulsification.
(36,37)
To utilize MoS
2
NSs as particle surfactants in the O/W system, we carefully tuned the surface properties of the original MoS
2
NSs to be amphiphilic by anchoring hydrophilic mercaptopropionic acid (MPA) and hydrophobic oleylamine (OLA) ligands.
(38â40)
Figure
1
a,b describes the synthetic route of the amphiphilic MoS
2
NSs and the fabrication of Pt NP-decorated hollow MoS
2
structures through the Pickering emulsification, respectively. Pristine MoS
2
NSs, denoted as
M0
, were synthesized by using the chemical exfoliation method, as reported previously.
(41,42)
The resulting
M0
exhibited a 1T-phase dominant structure in the TEM and the 1T/2H ratio was 9:1 by the XPS analysis (
Figure S1
).
M0
showed a hydrophilic surface with the
Z
-average size of 278 nm by dynamic light scattering (DLS) (
Figure S2
). Then, the pristine MoS
2
NSs were modified by varying the amounts of MPA and OLA molecules.
(43,44)
In order to verify that the ligands of MoS
2
affect the particle property as a surfactant, a series of three different modified MoS
2
NSs were synthesized with the different grafting density of MPA and OLA ligands: they were denoted as
M1
,
M2
, and
M3
, respectively. The modification of MoS
2
NSs by MPA/OLA ligands did not affect their size (
Figure S2
). The conjugation between the ligands and the MoS
2
NSs was confirmed by using attenuated total-reflectance Fourier transform infrared (ATR-FTIR) spectroscopy (
Figure
2
a). Unlike the
M0
,
(45)
the
M1
,
M2
, and
M3
exhibited peaks at 1462, 2854, and 2927 cm
â1
from the aliphatic group and 724 and 1578 cm
â1
from the alkene and amine groups, respectively.
(46,47)
Also, the peak intensities increased in the order of
M1
,
M2
, and
M3
. The areal chain densities (Î´) of the grafted ligands on the
M1
,
M2
, and
M3
were estimated from thermogravimetric analysis (
Figure S3
and
Table S1
). The obtained Î´ was between 3.9 and 5.4 chains nm
â2
,
(48)
comparable to the previously reported values for ligand densities on metal surfaces.
(49â52)
We further examined the surface properties of the
M0
,
M1
,
M2
, and
M3
by measuring the contact angles (
Table S2
) and calculated the surface tensions using the Wu model.
(53)
The surface tensions decreased from 65.9 to 46.3 mN m
â1
as the Î´ of ligands increased (
Figure
2
a), suggesting that the amphiphilicity of MoS
2
NSs was increased.

div.p:
Figure 2. (a) ATR-FTIR spectra and (b) calculated surface tension of
M0
,
M1
,
M2
, and
M3
. (câf) Optical micrographs of toluene-in-water Pickering emulsions stabilized by (c)
M0
, (d)
M1
, (e)
M2
, and (f)
M3
. (gâj) SEM images of PS particles covered by (g)
M0
, (h)
M1
, (i)
M2
, and (j)
M3
.

div.div:
For the development of hollow MoS
2
structures, the Pickering emulsification and subsequent evaporation process were used to generate the MoS
2
-covered PS particles (
[emailÂ protected]
2
) (
Figure
2
).
(54,55)
Different types of MoS
2
NSs (
i.e.
,
M0
,
M1
,
M2
, and
M3
) were applied to form the O/W emulsions (1:1 v/v of toluene/water and 0.25 mg mL
â1
of MoS
2
NS). The O/W droplets were formed from the experiments regardless of the volume ratio between oil and water. As shown in
Figure
2
c,
M0
was not able to stabilize the O/W interfaces, thus no Pickering emulsions were produced. By contrast, most of
M1
,
M2
, and
M3
can be located at the O/W interface because of their amphiphilic surface nature, producing the emulsions with high stability over 72 h (
Figure
2
dâf). However, each sample had a different stabilized volume of emulsions as well as droplet size, indicating the difference in the surfactant efficiency of
M1
,
M2
, and
M3
. The use of
M1
and
M2
resulted in relatively larger droplet sizes of 400 and 190 Î¼m in average diameter, respectively, and both solutions have less than 80 vol % of the emulsion among the total volume of the solution. In comparison, the use of
M3
produced much smaller droplets with an average size of 30 Î¼m in diameter. Also, over 90% of the whole solution was the emulsions, demonstrating the highest interfacial activity of
M3
.
(56,57)

These surfactant properties of different MoS
2
NSs also determined the size of
[emailÂ protected]
2
(
Figure
2
gâj).
(54)
The mixture of PS polymer solution in toluene (10 mg mL
â1
) and MoS
2
NS surfactants were emulsified in water, followed by slow evaporation of toluene. While no spherical particles were produced in the
M0
-based sample (
Figure
2
g), the spherical PS particles with the average diameters of 1710, 970, and 490 nm were produced for
M1
,
M2
, and
M3
(
Figure
2
hâj and
Figure S4
), respectively. The Î´ of ligands did not increase even if the feeding amounts of the ligands was increased over 4% v/v, leading to the similar surface tension between
M3
and the sample with 10% v/v. Thus,
M3
is the optimal surfactant for producing the
[emailÂ protected]
2
with the maximal surface area, and we used the
M3
-covered PS particles for further experiments in this work.

The Pt NPs are an essential component in the hydrogenation catalysts.
(58)
The Pt NPs on the surface of
M3
-covered PS particles (
[emailÂ protected]
2
/Pt) were produced by incorporating the Pt precursors through electrostatic interaction with the MoS
2
, followed by photoreduction (
Figure
3
a).
(59)
Then, the
[emailÂ protected]
2
/Pt samples were annealed at 400 Â°C in nitrogen gas (N
2
) for 1 h, leading to the decomposition and removal of the PS core. The resulting composite of Pt NP-incorporated hollow MoS
2
(h-MoS
2
/Pt) retained the spherical morphology but formed a hollow MoS
2
structure with an average diameter of 440 nm. The high-resolution transmittance electron microscopy (HRTEM) image of the h-MoS
2
/Pt shows the lattice planes of
fcc
Pt (111) and 2H-MoS
2
(100), corresponding to 2.2 and 2.7 Ã , respectively, indicating the presence of both Pt NPs and MoS
2
NSs (
Figure
3
b-c). During the thermal annealing process, the MoS
2
showed the phase transition from 1T (metallic) to 2H (semiconducting) phase corresponding to
Figure S5
and the previous report.
(38)
The average thickness of the h-MoS
2
shell was 5.4 nm, which corresponds to that of seven to eight-layered MoS
2
NSs.
(35,60)
In addition, energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mapping analysis of h-MoS
2
/Pt confirmed well-distributed Pt clusters on the surface of the MoS
2
templates (
Figure
3
c). Moreover, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis of h-MoS
2
/Pt further showed the chemical state of Pt (Pt
0
), Mo (Mo
4+
), and S (S
2â
) (
Figure S6
), indicating the existence of nonoxidized MoS
2
shell and metallic Pt NPs.

div.p:
Figure 3. (a) SEM image of
[emailÂ protected]
2
/Pt. (b) HRTEM image of h-MoS
2
/Pt. (c) High-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM image and elemental mapping images of h-MoS
2
/Pt. (d) N
2
adsorption and desorption isotherms of pristine MoS
2
and h-MoS
2
/Pt. (e) The pore size distribution of the samples. (f) XRD analysis of pristine MoS
2
, h-MoS
2,
and h-MoS
2
/Pt.

div.div:
To demonstrate the enhanced gas permeability and free volume of the h-MoS
2
/Pt, we performed N
2
adsorption/desorption analysis for the h-MoS
2
/Pt (
Figure
3
d). Pristine MoS
2
and exfoliated MoS
2
NSs were used as control samples, which were prepared by the exfoliation of commercial MoS
2
. The h-MoS
2
/Pt displayed type IV isotherms (mesoporous structures), whereas the pristine MoS
2
showed a nonporous structure. The specific surface areas calculated by BrunauerâEmmettâTeller (BET) analysis were 41.50 m
2
g
â1
for h-MoS
2
/Pt. This value was 4 times larger than the pristine MoS
2
(10.42 m
2
g
â1
) and 99 times larger than chemically exfoliated MoS
2
NSs (0.42 m
2
g
â1
) (
Figure S7
). In addition, the analysis of pore size distribution obtained from the BarrettâJoynerâHalenda (BJH) method supported the increase of meso- and macropore structures in the h-MoS
2
/Pt (
Figure
3
e): the total pore volume of h-MoS
2
/Pt (0.112 cm
3
g
â1
) was significantly increased compared with those of the pristine MoS
2
(0.039 cm
3
g
â1
) and exfoliated MoS
2
NS. We further investigated the surface morphologies of the materials after drop-coating on a substrate (
Figure S8
). In the case of MoS
2
NSs, they showed a nonporous structure due to the severe aggregation and self-stacking, as shown in previous articles.
(16,31)
In contrast, the h-MoS
2
displayed a highly porous structure.

Then, we conducted X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis to investigate the crystal structure of the samples (
Figure
3
f). The XRD patterns of MoS
2
NSs showed the high intensity of the MoS
2
(002) plane at 14Â° as a result of the stacking of MoS
2
NSs to the
c
-axis. On the other hand, the h-MoS
2
sample without Pt incorporation displayed a lower intensity of MoS
2
(002) plane than that of MoS
2
NSs because the ultrathin layer of MoS
2
NSs was well maintained in the hollow architectures. In addition, the XRD patterns of the h-MoS
2
/Pt exhibited the signatures of both
fcc
Pt (JCPDS no. 04-0802) and 2H-MoS
2
(JCPDS no. 37-1492) (
Figure
3
f), indicating that Pt NPs were well decorated on h-MoS
2
.

To investigate potential suitability of h-MoS
2
/Pt as room temperature chemical sensors for H
2
sensing, we fabricated h-MoS
2
/Pt-based sensors (see details in the
Experimental Section
). First, we tuned the loading amounts of Pt NPs in h-MoS
2
/Pt from 8.7 to 34.7 at %: sample 1 (with Pt = 8.7 at %), sample 2 (with Pt = 21.1 at %), and sample 3 (with Pt = 34.7 at %) (
Table S3
) to optimize the H
2
sensing properties of h-MoS
2
/Pt. We note that further loading of Pt NPs over 34.7 at % is difficult due to the dispersion stability of
[emailÂ protected]
2
. The Pt NPs enhanced the H
2
sensing properties of h-MoS
2
, but sample 1 and sample 2 showed relatively slow kinetics due to the small amounts of Pt. In comparison, sample 3 displayed significantly faster response speed than the other samples (
Figure S9
). Nevertheless, the overshooting phenomenon, the rapid changes in signal exceeding a final steady-state value, was caused by the fast gas reactions in sample 3 when exposed to high concentrations of H
2
.
(61)
We further monitored this overshooting response under various conditions in
Figure S10
. The related discussion is provided in the
Supporting Information
. Then, we used sample 3 to fabricate a representative h-MoS
2
/Pt chemical sensor. To elucidate the role of the hollow MoS
2
structure and Pt NPs of h-MoS
2
/Pt for H
2
sensing, we prepared the following control samples: (1) MoS
2
NSs (nonhollow structure, 0.42 m
2
g
â1
), (2) h-MoS
2
(hollow structure, 35.56 m
2
g
â1
), and (3) Pt NP-incorporated MoS
2
NSs (MoS
2
/Pt, nonhollow structure, 1.39 m
2
g
â1
). The control samples were annealed (400 Â°C under N
2
at 1 atm) to prepare h-MoS
2
(
Figure S11
, see details in the
Experimental Section
). The results of the baseline resistances of the sensors provide an important clue of the morphologies in both the MoS
2
hollow structure and Pt NPs in the h-MoS
2
/Pt (
Figure S12
). (i) There was a 10-fold higher baseline resistance of the h-MoS
2
(31 Â± 5 MÎ©) than that of the annealed (2H phase) MoS
2
NSs (3.2 Â± 0.6 MÎ©), which was a result of the reduced electrical pathways in the hollow MoS
2
structure by a point contact between the hollow spheres. (ii) However, the resistance (0.84 Â± 0.08 MÎ©) of h-MoS
2
/Pt was significantly decreased due to the effective electron transfer from MoS
2
to Pt NPs,
(62)
since the work function of MoS
2
(â4.36 eV)
(63)
is higher than that of Pt (â5.65 eV).
(64)

Next, we compared the H
2
sensing performance of the h-MoS
2
/Pt with those of the other reference samples under air atmosphere at room temperature (
Figure
4
a). The h-MoS
2
/Pt sample exhibited significant changes in resistance with fast response and recovery speed, whereas the other samples showed negligible changes in resistance. Importantly, the presence of Pt NPs on h-MoS
2
/Pt allowed for the detection of H
2
at a low level of 0.05% (
Figure
4
b and
Figure S9
). We calculated the sensing properties, in terms of the response (Î
R
g
/
R
a
), response time (
t
90
), and recovery time (
t
10
) (see details in the
Experimental Section
). The h-MoS
2
/Pt sample showed the highest response of 12.0% (at 4% of H
2
) compared with the pristine MoS
2
(0.39%), h-MoS
2
(0.12%), and MoS
2
/Pt (2.79%) (
Figure
4
c). Furthermore, the h-MoS
2
/Pt sensor had a noticeable response (Î
R
g
/
R
a
= 0.88%) even to 0.05% of H
2
, whereas the other samples were not able to detect H
2
below 1%. Additionally, the response time of h-MoS
2
/Pt was much faster (2.7 s for H
2
4%) (
Figure
4
d) than those of the pristine MoS
2
(540 s), h-MoS
2
(540 s), and MoS
2
/Pt (60 s). In particular, the h-MoS
2
/Pt sensor had a much faster recovery speed of 16.0 s at 4% of H
2
, compared with those of the other samples (540 s for MoS
2
NSs and h-MoS
2
and 60 s for MoS
2
/Pt) (
Figure
4
e). Therefore, these results confirm the synergistic contribution of hollow structure and Pt NPs to achieve the chemiresistive H
2
sensing performance with high response and fast sensing speed. Comparing our results to the highest performing sensors reported in the literature, our h-MoS
2
/Pt sensors outperformed them in the sensing speed (8.1 s) for the detection of H
2
1% among 2D material-based H
2
sensors operated at room temperature in air (
Figure
4
f and
Table S4
).
(28â30)

div.p:
Figure 4. Resistance changes of MoS
2
, h-MoS
2
, MoS
2
/Pt, and h-MoS
2
/Pt in response to (a) 1â4% and (b) 0.4â0.8% of H
2
. Calculated sensing properties: (c) response, (d) response time, and (e) recovery time. (f) Comparison of response times of 2D material-based H
2
sensors. (Abbreviations: PMMA is poly(methyl methacrylate) and GR is graphene.).

div.div:
We further examined parameters that are important for sensing technologies: reversibility, stability, selectivity, and robustness. The h-MoS
2
/Pt sensor exhibited stable and reversible response traces to cyclic exposures of 1% and 4% of H
2
(
Figure S13
). The stability of h-MoS
2
/Pt is also supported by XPS analysis. The high-resolution XPS spectra of the h-MoS
2
/Pt after sensing tests to 4% of H
2
are the same as those of fresh h-MoS
2
/Pt (
Figure S14
), revealing that the H
2
reaction on h-MoS
2
/Pt is reversible without chemical changes. In addition, the h-MoS
2
/Pt sensor exhibited enhanced cross-responses to H
2
against the other four analytes (toluene [C
6
H
5
CH
3
], nitrogen dioxide [NO
2
], formaldehyde [HCHO], and hydrogen sulfide [H
2
S]) (
Figure S15
). In contrast to the h-MoS
2
/Pt, the pristine MoS
2
NSs and h-MoS
2
exhibited high NO
2
selectivity with a very low H
2
response, as reported in previous studies on TMD-based sensors.
(22â24)
Thus, these results suggest that the Pt NPs on the h-MoS
2
/Pt sensor produced chemiresistive H
2
sensing behaviors on MoS
2
. Furthermore, the h-MoS
2
/Pt showed reproducible responses toward H
2
in the presence of water (relative humidity = 95%). The response speed of the sensors became relatively slower in humid atmospheres, while the sensitivity was increased, compared with the responses measured in dry conditions (
Figure S16
). For example, the response time of the h-MoS
2
/Pt to H
2
1.25% was increased from 8 s in dry air to 41 s in humid air. At the same time, the responsivity was increased from 9% to 15% in humid air. This can be attributed to the adsorption of water and the generation of oxygen species including hydroxyl ions on the surface of h-MoS
2
/Pt.
(65)
This leads to an electron-depleted surface and increases the potential energy barrier between the grain boundaries of materials.
(66,67)
When the sensor is exposed to H
2
, the adsorbed oxygen species are reduced followed by a decrease of the energy barrier, resulting in an increase of sensing responses. However, the desorption of water molecules for H
2
sensing induces a response delay. This humidity dependency of the sensors is an inherent issue in chemiresistive sensors,
(68â70)
but their performance is expected to be improved by the introduction of humidity screening catalysts or membranes, as previously demonstrated.
(71,72)

Figure
5
a schematically describes the sensing mechanism of h-MoS
2
/Pt. We suggest that the improvement in the H
2
sensing performance of the h-MoS
2
/Pt is mainly attributed to (1) the hollow structure of ultrathin MoS
2
shell and (2) the spillover effect of Pt NPs (
Figure
5
a). First, the hollow structure increases the accessibility to surface-active sites of MoS
2
NS shell and facilitates gas diffusion inside the sensing layers, as shown by the increases of N
2
adsorption and desorption isotherms (
Figure
3
d). Second, Pt NPs dissociate H
2
molecules and spillover them to MoS
2
, thus promoting the surface reaction between H
2
and MoS
2
.
(73)
To support our hypothesis, we calculated activation energies (
E
act
) for H
2
reactions on h-MoS
2
and h-MoS
2
/Pt. The response times (
t
90
) and response rates (Ï
res
=
t
90
â1
) of the sensors were measured with H
2
1% at different operating temperatures (
T
= 25, 50, 100, and 150 Â°C) (
Figures S17 and 18
and
Table S5
). Then, the
E
act
of the sensors for H
2
reaction was obtained by using the Arrhenius equation as defined in
eq 1
.
(1)
Here,
A
0
is the pre-exponential factor and
R
is the universal gas constant. Based on these calculations, the
E
act
was dramatically decreased from 682.77 cal mol
â1
for the h-MoS
2
to 5.19 cal mol
â1
for the h-MoS
2
/Pt (
Figure
5
b). The
E
act
calculation in this work includes all reactions (gas diffusion, surface reactions, and charge transfers) in H
2
sensing. This tendency of
E
act
matched with the mechanisms of dissociative H
2
adsorption on MoS
2
and Pt. In the case of MoS
2
, dissociative H
2
adsorption includes three steps:
(74)
(1) H
2
molecules are adsorbed on S sites in MoS
2
(Î
E
= +0.6 eV/H
2
), (2) adsorbed H
2
molecules are dissociated into MoâH and SâH pairs (Î
E
= +0.15 eV/H
2
), and (3) H diffuses and forms SâH groups at Mo edges (Î
E
= â0.2 eV/H
2
). The aforementioned reaction process between H
2
and MoS
2
is exothermic, but there are two potential energy barriers in H
2
adsorption (step 1) and dissociation (step 2). On the other hand, dissociative H
2
adsorption on Pt (PtâH) is most stable at the (111) facet of
fcc
Pt (â0.85 eV/H
2
) with nearly flat activation energy,
(75,76)
which allows diffusion of the dissociated H atoms to supports,
i.e.
, H
2
spillover due to the flat potential surfaces of
fcc
Pt for H hopping.
(76)
Therefore, our calculations on
E
act
indicate that the H
2
sensing of h-MoS
2
/Pt is related to the H
2
spillover induced by Pt NPs.

div.p:
Figure 5. (a) Schematic illustration of sensing mechanisms of h-MoS
2
/Pt. (b) Calculated
E
act
for H
2
reaction on the sensors.
In situ
Raman spectra of the samples when exposed to H
2
4% over a period of 300 s: (c) h-MoS
2
/Pt and (d) h-MoS
2
.

div.div:
To further support the spillover of H
2
onto h-MoS
2
of h-MoS
2
/Pt sensors, we performed an
in situ
Raman spectroscopy. Raman spectra were collected over a period of 300 s after exposure to 4% of H
2
. The fresh h-MoS
2
/Pt showed two distinct peaks of the in-plane vibration (
E
2g
1
) of MoS
2
at 382.32 cm
â1
and the sulfur atomic vibration to the out-of-plane (
A
1
g
) at 405.07 cm
â1
(
Figure
5
c). The frequency difference (22.75 cm
â1
) between
A
1
g
and
E
2g
1
indicates that the h-MoS
2
/Pt consists of few-layered MoS
2
.
(77)
Interestingly, the
A
1
g
peak of the h-MoS
2
/Pt sample was shifted to lower wavenumber after H
2
exposure for 60 s, while the in-plane vibration of MoS
2
did not change (
Figure
5
c). This shift is a result of the interaction between donated electrons and MoS
2
,
(78)
thus suggesting that dissociated hydrogen by Pt NPs is adsorbed on h-MoS
2
. The fast change of the Raman peak is also consistent with the fast sensing speed of h-MoS
2
/Pt. In contrast, the
in situ
Raman spectra of the control sample (h-MoS
2
) did not exhibit any shift due to the slow reaction speed (
Figure
5
d).

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
In conclusion, we developed a porous sensing platform, h-MoS
2
/Pt, with improved sensing speed, selectivity, and stability. The design of ultrathin MoS
2
NSs with controlled surface properties is a key to fabricate the ultrathin MoS
2
shell by Pickering emulsification. The h-MoS
2
/Pt sensors showed superior H
2
sensing properties at room temperature in air (response, 8.1 s for H
2
1% and 2.7 s for H
2
4%;, recovery, 16.0 s for both 1% and 4% H
2
). We investigated the sensing mechanism of h-MoS
2
/Pt by comparing their performance with those of the reference samples at various conditions, demonstrating that both the high surface area of ultrathin MoS
2
shell and the spillover effect of Pt NPs in h-MoS
2
/Pt sensors contributed to these outstanding performances. Our strategy can be extended to the simple fabrication of a 3D hollow structure based on various types of TMDs and metal NPs for the potential optical, electrical, and catalytic applications.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
First, we synthesized mono- or few-layered MoS
2
NSs,
M0
, through the chemical exfoliation of MoS
2
powders using BuLi.
(41,42)
A solution of
n
-BuLi (3 mL, 1.6 M in hexane) was added into MoS
2
powder (300 mg) and stirred for 48 h at room temperature under N
2
conditions. Then, the mixture centrifuged (10â¯000 rpm, 5 min), and the precipitates were redispersed and sonicated for 1 h in the DI water (300 mL). After eliminating the residue ions and small molecules through the dialysis, single- or few-layered MoS
2
NSs in water were obtained (1 mg mL
â1
, 100 mL).

Subsequently, we obtained pellets by centrifuging the
M0
aqueous solution (0.7 mg mL
â1
). Equal volumes of OLA and MPA in chloroform (1, 2, and 4% v/v for
M1
,
M2
, and
M3
, respectively) were dropped on the
M0
, and the solution was vigorously mixed. After sonication and stirring for 1 h each, the mixture was washed and centrifuged three times (10â¯000 rpm, 5 min) using chloroform to remove residual ligands.

The h-MoS
2
was prepared by using Pickering emulsification. The DI water and PS dissolved toluene (or chloroform) (1% w/v) with the 4:1 of volume ratio were added into the products until the final concentration of modified MoS
2
NS became 1 mg mL
â1
. To estimate the amount of the organic ligands on the modified MoS
2
NSs, the weight fractions of MoS
2
and ligands in the products were measured by thermal gravimetric analysis. The solution was stirred for 1 h and emulsified using a vortex for 2 min. Then, the organic solvent was slowly evaporated at room temperature for 48 h. Gentle centrifugation (1000 rpm, 3 min) was used to remove large aggregation. Then, the supernatant consisting of the MoS
2
-covered PS particles (
[emailÂ protected]
2
) was centrifuged and redispersed in the DI water at the desired concentration. To produce the H-MoS
2
, the
[emailÂ protected]
2
solution was deposited on a glass substrate and allowed to dry in the oven at 60 Â°C. After collecting the powders, the sample was annealed at 400 Â°C under N
2
gas at atmospheric pressure using a furnace for 1 h to decompose the inner PS particles (yield <10%). Finally, the hollow structured h-MoS
2
was collected as a dark powder.

To produce the h-MoS
2
/Pt, the potassium tetrachloroplatinate (K
2
PtCl
4
) solution (30 mM) was added dropwise into the
[emailÂ protected]
2
solution. For the optimization, 200, 600, and 1200 Î¼L of K
2
PtCl
4
solution was added into 7 mL of the
[emailÂ protected]
2
suspension (7.5 mg mL
â1
), respectively. The mixture was stirred under UV irradiation for 12 h at 20 Â°C, followed by washing with DI water to remove the unreacted Pt precursor (yield 92â97%). Similar to the process for h-MoS
2
, the sample was collected as a powder and was annealed at 400 Â°C for 1 h (yield <10%). The h-MoS
2
/Pt was obtained as a dark powder.

The sensing materials (4 mg) were homogeneously dispersed in ethanol (200 Î¼L), separately. Then, the suspension of each material was drop-coated on a sensing substrate (Al
2
O
3
; area, 2.5 mm Ã 2.5 mm; thickness, 0.2 mm) that was patterned with two parallel Au electrodes (distance, 70 Î¼m) on the front and a Pt microheater on the back (
Figure S19
). The sensing tests were conducted using a homemade measurement setup described in our previous article.
(79)
In detail, the sensing measurements were carried out in a sealed chamber and the sensors were operated at room temperature in air. Before sensing measurements, the sensors were stabilized in air for 3 h. Then, the sensors were exposed to H
2
for 10 min and recovered in fresh air for 10 min. H
2
concentration was controlled in the range of 0.005â4%. Resistances of the sensors were monitored using an acquisition system (34972, Agilent) in real time. The sensors were also exposed to 20 ppm of various analytes, including toluene (C
6
H
5
CH
3
), nitrogen dioxide (NO
2
), formaldehyde (HCHO), and hydrogen sulfide (H
2
S). The operating temperature of the sensors was modulated by using a Pt microheater that was applied by a certain voltage using a DC power supply (E3647A, Agilent). The response is defined as a ratio of maximum resistance change (Î
R
g
) to baseline resistance (
R
a
) in air. Response times and recovery times were calculated by the time taken for a resistance increase from
R
a
to 0.9Î
R
g
and for a resistance decrease from Î
R
g
to 0.1Î
R
g
, respectively.

Raman spectra of the samples were measured on a Raman spectrometer (Horiba LabRAM HR Evolution Visible_NIR) using an excitation wavelength of 514 nm. The spectra were collected with the following parameters in place: edge filter = 1%; grafting = 2400; objective = 50Ã; hole = 100 Î¼m; wavenumber cutoff = 10 cm
â1
; collected spectrum = from 350 to 450 cm
â1
; integration time = 60 s. The samples were deposed on the plasma-treated silicon wafer and enveloped in the quartz cell under N
2
atmosphere. The Raman analysis was performed simultaneously as exposing the 5% hydrogen gas (N
2
balance) into the quartz cell.

A review. Converting all U.S. onroad vehicles to hydrogen fuel-cell vehicles (HFCVs) may improve air quality, health, and climate significantly, whether the hydrogen is produced by steam reforming of natural gas, wind electrolysis, or coal gasification. Most benefits would result from eliminating current vehicle exhaust. Wind and natural gas HFCVs offer the greatest potential health benefits and could save 3700 to 6400 U.S. lives annually. Wind HFCVs should benefit climate most. An all-HFCV fleet would hardly affect tropospheric water vapor concns. Conversion to coal HFCVs may improve health but would damage climate more than fossil/elec. hybrids. The real cost of hydrogen from wind electrolysis may be below that of U.S. gasoline.

A review. Hydrogen sensors are of increasing importance in connection with the development and expanded use of hydrogen gas as an energy carrier and as a chem. reactant. There are an immense no. of sensors reported in the literature for hydrogen detection and in this work these sensors are classified into eight different operating principles. Characteristic performance parameters of these sensor types, such as measuring range, sensitivity, selectivity and response time are reviewed and the latest technol. developments are reported. Testing and validation of sensor performance are described in relation to standardization and use in potentially explosive atmospheres so as to identify the requirements on hydrogen sensors for practical applications.

Hysteresis-Free Nanoplasmonic Pd-Au Alloy Hydrogen Sensors
Wadell, Carl; Nugroho, Ferry Anggoro Ardy; Lidstroem, Emil; Iandolo, Beniamino; Wagner, Jakob B.; Langhammer, Christoph
Nano Letters
(
2015
),
15
(
5
),
3563-3570
CODEN:
NALEFD
; ISSN:
1530-6984
.
(
American Chemical Society
)
The recent market introduction of hydrogen fuel cell cars and the prospect of a hydrogen economy have drastically accelerated the need for safe and accurate detection of hydrogen. In this Letter, the authors study the use of arrays of nanofabricated Pd-Au alloy nanoparticles as plasmonic optical hydrogen sensors. By increasing the amt. of Au in the alloy nanoparticles up to 25 atom %, the authors are able to suppress the hysteresis between hydrogen absorption and desorption, thereby increasing the sensor accuracy to <5% throughout the studied 1 mbar to 1 bar hydrogen pressure range. Also, the authors observe an 8-fold abs. sensitivity enhancement at low hydrogen pressures compared to sensors made of pure Pd, and an improved sensor response time to below one 2nd within the 0-40 mbar pressure range, i.e., below the flammability limit, by engineering the nanoparticle size.

Nugroho, Ferry A. A.; Darmadi, Iwan; Cusinato, Lucy; Susarrey-Arce, Arturo; Schreuders, Herman; Bannenberg, Lars J.; da Silva Fanta, Alice Bastos; Kadkhodazadeh, Shima; Wagner, Jakob B.; Antosiewicz, Tomasz J.; Hellman, Anders; Zhdanov, Vladimir P.; Dam, Bernard; Langhammer, Christoph

Nature Research

Hydrogen-air mixts. are highly flammable. Hydrogen sensors are therefore of paramount importance for timely leak detection during handling. However, existing solns. do not meet the stringent performance targets set by stakeholders, while deactivation due to poisoning, for example by carbon monoxide, is a widely unsolved problem. Here we present a plasmonic metal-polymer hybrid nanomaterial concept, where the polymer coating reduces the apparent activation energy for hydrogen transport into and out of the plasmonic nanoparticles, while deactivation resistance is provided via a tailored tandem polymer membrane. In concert with an optimized vol.-to-surface ratio of the signal transducer uniquely offered by nanoparticles, this enables subsecond sensor response times. Simultaneously, hydrogen sorption hysteresis is suppressed, sensor limit of detection is enhanced, and sensor operation in demanding chem. environments is enabled, without signs of long-term deactivation. In a wider perspective, our work suggests strategies for next-generation optical gas sensors with functionalities optimized by hybrid material engineering.

The oxygen, O2, in air interferes with the detection of H2 by palladium (Pd)-based H2 sensors, including Pd nanowires (NWs), depressing the sensitivity and retarding the response/recovery speed in air-relative to N2 or Ar. Here, the authors describe the prepn. of H2 sensors in which a nanofiltration layer consisting of a Zn metal-org. framework (MOF) is assembled onto Pd NWs. Polyhedron particles of Zn-based zeolite imidazole framework (ZIF-8) were synthesized on lithog. patterned Pd NWs, leading to the creation of ZIF-8/Pd NW bilayered H2 sensors. The ZIF-8 filter has many micropores (0.34 nm for gas diffusion) which allows for the predominant penetration of hydrogen mols. with a kinetic diam. of 0.289 nm, whereas relatively larger gas mols. including oxygen (0.345 nm) and nitrogen (0.364 nm) in air are effectively screened, resulting in superior hydrogen sensing properties. Very importantly, the Pd NWs filtered by ZIF-8 membrane (Pd
[emailÂ protected]
) reduced the H2 response amplitude slightly (ÎR/R0 = 3.5% to 1% of H2vs. 5.9% for Pd NWs) and showed 20-fold faster recovery (7 s to 1% of H2) and response (10 s to 1% of H2) speed compared to that of pristine Pd NWs (164 s for response and 229 s for recovery to 1% of H2). These outstanding results, which are mainly attributed to the mol. sieving and acceleration effect of ZIF-8 covered on Pd NWs, rank highest in H2 sensing speed among room-temp. Pd-based H2 sensors.

Carbon Nanotube Chemical Sensors
Schroeder, Vera; Savagatrup, Suchol; He, Maggie; Lin, Sibo; Swager, Timothy M.

Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) promise to advance a no. of real-world technologies. Of these applications, they are particularly attractive for uses in chem. sensors for environmental and health monitoring. However, chem. sensors based on CNTs are often lacking in selectivity, and the elucidation of their sensing mechanisms remains challenging. This review is a comprehensive description of the parameters that give rise to the sensing capabilities of CNT-based sensors and the application of CNT-based devices in chem. sensing. This review begins with the discussion of the sensing mechanisms in CNT-based devices, the chem. methods of CNT functionalization, architectures of sensors, performance parameters, and theor. models used to describe CNT sensors. It then discusses the expansive applications of CNT-based sensors to multiple areas including environmental monitoring, food and agriculture applications, biol. sensors, and national security. The discussion of each analyte focuses on the strategies used to impart selectivity and the mol. interactions between the selector and the analyte. Finally, the review concludes with a brief outlook over future developments in the field of chem. sensors and their prospects for commercialization.

A Nose for Hydrogen Gas: Fast, Sensitive H2 Sensors Using Electrodeposited Nanomaterials
Penner, Reginald M.

A review. Hydrogen gas (H2) is odorless and flammable at concns. above 4% (vol./vol.) in air. Sensors capable of detecting it rapidly at lower concns. are needed to "sniff" for leaked H2 wherever it is used. Exposure to H2 causes a resistance increase, as Pd metal is converted into more resistive palladium hydride (PdHx). Sensors based upon Pd alloy films, developed in the early 1990s, were both too slow and too insensitive to meet the requirements of H2 safety sensing. In this Account, we describe the development of H2 sensors that are based upon electrodeposited nanomaterials. This story begins with the rise to prominence of nanowire-based sensors in 2001 and our demonstration that year of the first nanowire-based H2 sensor. The Pd nanowires used in these expts. were prepd. by electrodepositing Pd at linear step-edge defects on a graphite electrode surface. In 2005, lithog. patterned nanowire electrodeposition (LPNE) provided the capability to pattern single Pd nanowires on dielecs. using electrodeposition. LPNE also provided control over the nanowire thickness (Â±1 nm) and width (Â±10-15%). Using single Pd nanowires, it was demonstrated in 2010 that smaller nanowires responded more rapidly to H2 exposure. Heating the nanowire using Joule self-heating (2010) also dramatically accelerated sensor response and recovery, leading to the conclusion that thermally activated H2 chemisorption and desorption of H2 were rate-limiting steps in sensor response to and recovery from H2 exposure. Platinum (Pt) nanowires, studied in 2012, showed an inverted resistance response to H2 exposure, i.e., the resistance of Pt nanowires decreased instead of increased upon H2 exposure. H2 dissociatively chemisorbs at a Pt surface to form Pt-H, but in contrast to Pd, it stays on the Pt surface. Pt nanowires showed a faster response to H2 exposure than Pd nanowires operating at the same elevated temp., but they had a surprising disadvantage: The resistance change obsd. for Pt nanowires was exactly the same for all H2 concns. Electron surface scattering was implicated in the mechanism for these sensors. Work on Pt nanowires lead in 2015 to the prepn. of Pd nanowires that were electrochem. modified with thin Pt layers (
[emailÂ protected]
nanowires). Relative to Pd nanowires,
[emailÂ protected]
nanowires showed accelerated response and recovery to H2 while retaining the same high sensitivity to H2 concn. seen for sensors based upon pure Pd nanowires. A new chapter in H2 sensing (2017) involves the replacement of metal nanowires with carbon nanotube ropes decorated with electrodeposited Pd nanoparticles (NPs). Even higher sensitivity and faster sensor response and recovery are enabled by this sensor architecture. Sensor properties are strongly dependent on the size and size monodispersity of the Pd NPs, with smaller NPs yielding higher sensitivity and more rapid response/recovery. We hope the lessons learned from this science over 15 years will catalyze the development of sensors based upon electrodeposited nanomaterials for gases other than H2.

Hydrogen sensors and hydrogen-activated switches were fabricated from arrays of mesoscopic palladium wires. These palladium mesowire arrays were prepd. by electrodeposition onto graphite surfaces and were transferred onto a cyanoacrylate film. Exposure to hydrogen gas caused a rapid ( < 75 ms) reversible decrease in the resistance of the array that correlated with the hydrogen concn. at 2-10%. The sensor response appears to involve the closing of nanoscopic gaps or break junctions in wires caused by the dilation of palladium grains undergoing hydrogen absorption. Wire arrays in which all wires possessed nanoscopic gaps reverted to open circuits in the absence of hydrogen gas.

This work reports on the hydrogen sensing abilities of palladium (Pd)-capped magnesium (Mg) bimetallic ultra-thin films, which were prepd. by RF magnetron sputtering. The metal loading and the compn. of the quantum-sized Pd-capped Mg nanoparticles (NPs) were carefully controlled by varying the deposition conditions of the RF magnetron sputtering system. The as-fabricated structure shows hydrogenation at room temp. and dehydrogenation at increased temps. The change in elec. resistance during the hydrogenation/dehydrogenation process is found to be reversible. Along with this, the as-fabricated sensor also showed remarkable advantages, such as a large detection range (1-40,000 ppm) and fast response time. For a 10,000 ppm (1 vol.%) H2 concn. at room temp., a response time of 6 s was obsd. The fabricated sensor also exhibited good selectivity and a negligible humidity effect over the entire detection range. These Pd-capped Mg bimetallic ultra-thin films deposited on alumina (Al2O3) substrates can be used as a fast response, affordable, and low-temp. hydrogen sensing material.

A review. Highly sensitive and selective chem. sensors are needed for use in a wide range of applications such as environmental toxic gas monitoring, disease diagnosis, and food quality control. Although some chemiresistive sensors have been commercialized, grand challenges still remain: ppb-level sensitivity, accurate cross-selectivity, and long-term stability. Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) with record-breaking surface areas and ultrahigh porosity are ideal sensing materials because chem. sensors rely highly on surface reactions. In addn., MOFs can be used as a membrane to utilize their unique gas adsorption and sepn. characteristics. Furthermore, the use of MOFs as precursors to enable facile prodn. of various nanostructures is further combined with other functional materials. Based on these fascinating features of MOFs, there have been great efforts to elucidate reaction mechanisms and address limitations in MOF-based chemiresistors. In this review, we present a comprehensive overview and recent progress in chemiresistive sensors developed by using pure MOFs, MOF membranes, and MOF derivs.

Proton redn. is one of the most fundamental and important reactions in nature. MoS2 edges have been identified as the active sites for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) electrocatalysis. Designing mol. mimics of MoS2 edge sites is an attractive strategy to understand the underlying catalytic mechanism of different edge sites and improve their activities. Herein we report a dimeric mol. analog [Mo2S12]2-, as the smallest unit possessing both the terminal and bridging disulfide ligands. Our electrochem. tests show that [Mo2S12]2- is a superior heterogeneous HER catalyst under acidic conditions. Computations suggest that the bridging disulfide ligand of [Mo2S12]2- exhibits a hydrogen adsorption free energy near zero (-0.05 eV). This work helps shed light on the rational design of HER catalysts and biomimetics of hydrogen-evolving enzymes.

A review. Two-dimensional (2D) transition-metal dichalcogenide (TMD) nanosheets have emerged as a fascinating new class of materials for catalysis. These nanosheets are active for several important catalysis reactions including hydrogen evolution from water. The rich chem. of TMDs combined with numerous strategies that allow tuning of their electronic properties make these materials very attractive for understanding the fundamental principles of electro- and photocatalysis, as well as for developing highly efficient, renewable, and affordable catalysts for large-scale prodn. of hydrogen. Recent developments are highlighted and important challenges in using TMDs as catalysts are also discussed.

A review; layered transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) (MoS2, MoSe2, WS2, WSe2, etc.) are a chem. diverse class of compds. having band gaps from 0 to â¼2 eV and remarkable electrochem. properties. The band gaps and electrochem. properties of TMDs can be tuned by exchanging the transition metal or chalcogenide elements. After a brief description of the most commonly followed synthetic routes to prep. TMDs, we wish to highlight in this review the diverse electrochem. applications of MoS2, a representative and well-studied TMD, which range from its use as catalysts in hydrogen evolution reactions to its adoption in supercapacitors, batteries, solar cells, and hydrogen storage.

Royal Society of Chemistry

During the last decade, two-dimensional materials (2DMs) have attracted great attention due to their unique chem. and phys. properties, which make them appealing platforms for diverse applications in opto-electronic devices, energy generation and storage, and sensing. Among their various extraordinary properties, 2DMs possess high surface area-to-vol. ratios and ultra-high surface sensitivity to the environment, which are key characteristics for applications in chem. sensing. Furthermore, 2DMs' superior elec. and optical properties, combined with their excellent mech. characteristics such as robustness and flexibility, make these materials ideal components for the fabrication of a new generation of high-performance chem. sensors. Depending on the specific device, 2DMs can be tailored to interact with various chem. species at the non-covalent level, making them powerful platforms for fabricating devices exhibiting a high sensitivity towards detection of various analytes including gases, ions and small biomols. Here, we will review the most enlightening recent advances in the field of chem. sensors based on atomically-thin 2DMs and we will discuss the opportunities and the challenges towards the realization of novel hybrid materials and sensing devices.

The chemistry of two-dimensional layered transition metal dichalcogenide nanosheets
Chhowalla Manish; Shin Hyeon Suk; Eda Goki; Li Lain-Jong; Loh Kian Ping; Zhang Hua
Nature chemistry
(
2013
),
5
(
4
),
263-75
ISSN:
.
Ultrathin two-dimensional nanosheets of layered transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) are fundamentally and technologically intriguing. In contrast to the graphene sheet, they are chemically versatile. Mono- or few-layered TMDs - obtained either through exfoliation of bulk materials or bottom-up syntheses - are direct-gap semiconductors whose bandgap energy, as well as carrier type (n- or p-type), varies between compounds depending on their composition, structure and dimensionality. In this Review, we describe how the tunable electronic structure of TMDs makes them attractive for a variety of applications. They have been investigated as chemically active electrocatalysts for hydrogen evolution and hydrosulfurization, as well as electrically active materials in opto-electronics. Their morphologies and properties are also useful for energy storage applications such as electrodes for Li-ion batteries and supercapacitors.

Surface modification or decoration of ultrathin MoS2 films with chem. moieties is appealing since nanointerfacing can functionalize MoS2 films with bonus potentials. A facile and effective method for microlandscaping of Au nanoparticles (NPs) on few-layer MoS2 films is developed. This approach 1st employs a focused laser beam to premodify the MoS2 films to achieve active surface domains with unbound sulfur. When the activated surface is subsequently immersed in AuCl3 soln., Au NPs preferentially decorate onto the modified regions. As a result, Au NPs can be selectively and locally anchored onto designated regions on the MoS2 surface. With a scanning laser beam, microlandscapes comprising of Au NPs decorated on laser-defined micropatterns are constructed. By varying the laser power, reaction time and thickness of the MoS2 films, the size and d. of the NPs can be controlled. The resulting hybrid materials are demonstrated as efficient Raman active surfaces for the detection of arom. mols. with high sensitivity.

2D materials have exciting prospects for chem. sensing devices due to their exceptional elec., mech., and surface properties. Various 2D materials, which include graphene, transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs), and boron/carbon nitride, have been suggested as potential chem. sensing materials. In the present study, we accurately compare the chem. sensing performances (response/recovery time, selectivity, molar response factor, and adsorption behavior) of BP, MoS2, and graphene. Dynamic sensing response, sensitivity, selectivity, and response time all point to BP being the superior gas sensing material.

Red light illumination with photon energy matching the direct band gap of CVD grown single-layer MoS2 with Au metal electrodes was used to induce a photocurrent which was employed instead of dark current for NO2 gas sensing. The resulting Au/MoS2/Au optoelectronic gas sensor showed a significant enhancement of the device sensitivity S toward ppb level of NO2 gas exposure reaching S = 4.9%/ppb (4900%/ppm), where S is a slope of dependence of relative change of the sensor resistance on NO2 concn. Further optimization of the MoS2-based optoelectronic gas sensor by using graphene (Gr) with a work function lower than that of Au for the elec. contacts to the MoS2 channel allowed an increase of photocurrent. The limit of detection of NO2 gas at the level of 0.1 ppb was obtained for the MoS2 channel with graphene electrodes coated by Au. This value was calcd. using exptl. obtained sensitivity and noise values and exceeds the U.S. Environment Protection Agency requirement for NO2 gas detection at ppb level.

This article is the first demonstration of a molybdenum disulfide (MoS2)/tricobalt tetraoxide (Co3O4) nanocomposite film sensor toward NH3 detection. The MoS2/Co3O4 film sensor was fabricated on a substrate with interdigital electrodes via layer-by-layer self-assembly route. The surface morphol., nanostructure, and elemental compn. of the MoS2/Co3O4 samples were examd. by SEM, transmission electron microscopy, X-ray diffraction, energy-dispersive spectrometry, and XPS. The characterization results confirmed its successful prepn. and rationality. The NH3 sensing properties of the sensor for ultra-low-concn. detection were investigated at room temp. The exptl. results revealed that high sensitivity, good repeatability, stability, and selectivity and fast response/recovery characteristics were achieved by the sensor toward NH3. Moreover, the MoS2/Co3O4 nanocomposite film sensor exhibited significant enhancement in ammonia-sensing properties in comparison with the MoS2 and Co3O4 counterparts. The underlying sensing mechanisms of the MoS2/Co3O4 nanocomposite toward ammonia were ascribed to the layered nanostructure, synergistic effect, and heterojunction created at the interface of n-type MoS2 and p-type Co3O4. The synthesized MoS2/Co3O4 nanocomposite proved to be an excellent candidate for constructing high-performance ammonia sensor for various applications.

MoS2 nanosheets were attracting increasing research interests due to their unique material properties. However, the lack of a reliable large-scale prodn. method impedes their practical applications. Here a facile, efficient, and scalable method for the fabrication of high-concn. aq. dispersion of MoS2 nanosheets using combined grinding and sonication is reported. The 26.7 mg/mL concn. achieved is the highest concn. in an aq. soln. reported up to now. Grinding generates pure shear forces to detach the MoS2 layers from the bulk materials. Subsequent sonication further breaks larger crystallites into smaller crystallites, which promotes the dispersion of MoS2 nanosheets in ethanol/water solns. The exfoliation process establishes a new paradigm in the top-down fabrication of 2D nanosheets in aq. soln. In the meantime, MoS2-based sensing film produced using this approach has successfully demonstrated the feasibility of a low-cost and efficient NH3 gas sensor using ink-jet printing as a viable method.

A facile, scalable and low-cost strategy for fabricating hydrogen sensors with few-layered Pd-functionalized MoS2 according to a simple soln. process is reported. The sensors were prepd. by drop-casting a MoS2-contg. soln. onto a SiO2 substrate and functionalizing the surface of the MoS2 with Pd using evapn. Patterned deposition of Cr/Au on top of the MoS2-coated SiO2 substrate was then performed using evapn. through a shadow mask to place the micro electrodes on the substrate. The fabricated Pd-MoS2 sensors successfully detected hydrogen gas dild. by air at room temp. With exposure to hydrogen gas, the Pd was converted to palladium hydride, which has a lower work function than MoS2, resulting in the transfer of electrons from palladium hydride to MoS2, thereby decreasing the resistance of the sensor. The functionalized MoS2 showed a 35.3% resistance change when exposed to a 1% hydrogen-contg. gas, while the pristine MoS2 showed no reaction. The lower limit of detection of the resulting functionalized MoS2 sensor was 50 ppm.

The sensor offers the advantages of lightwt., mech. durability, room temp. operation, and high sensitivity. The WS2-Pd composite film exhibits sensitivity (R1/R2, the ratio of the initial resistance to final resistance of the sensor) of 7.8 to 50 000 ppm hydrogen. Furthermore, the ease of fabrication holds great potential for scalable and low-cost manufg. of hydrogen sensors.

This paper demonstrates a hydrogen gas sensor based on palladium-tin oxide- molybdenum disulfide (Pd-SnO2/MoS2) ternary hybrid via hydrothermal route. The morphologies, microstructures and compositional characteristics of the Pd-SnO2/MoS2 nanocomposite were sufficiently examd. by X-ray diffraction (XRD), Raman spectroscopy (RS), nitrogen sorption anal., energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS), SEM, transmission electron microscope (TEM) and XPS. The gas-sensing performances of the Pd-SnO2/MoS2 sensor were investigated by exposed to different concns. of hydrogen gas from 30 ppm to 5000 ppm at room temp. The exptl. results showed that the hydrogen gas sensor has a quite sensitive response, swift response-recovery time, good repeatability and selectivity toward hydrogen gas. Furthermore, the effect of Pd loading in the hybrid on the hydrogen gas sensing was investigated. The sensing mechanism of the Pd-SnO2/MoS2 sensor was attributed to the synergistic effect of the ternary nanostructures and the modulation of potential barrier with electron transfer. This work indicates that the as-prepd. Pd-SnO2/MoS2 composite is a candidate for detecting hydrogen gas in various applications at room temp.

Ultrathin two-dimensional (2D) nanosheets of layered transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs), such as MoS2, TiS2, TaS2, WS2, MoSe2, WSe2, etc., are emerging as a class of key materials in chem. and electronics due to their intriguing chem. and electronic properties. The ability to prep. these TMD nanosheets in high yield and large scale via various methods has led to increasing studies on their hybridization with other materials to create novel functional composites, aiming to engineer their chem., phys. and electronic properties and thus achieve good performance for some specific applications. In this crit. review, we will introduce the recent progress in hybrid nanoarchitectures based on 2D TMD nanosheets. Their synthetic strategies, properties and applications are systematically summarized and discussed, with emphasis on those new appealing structures, properties and functions. In addn., we will also give some perspectives on the challenges and opportunities in this promising research area.

The exploration of anode materials for lithium ion batteries (LIBs) or sodium ion batteries (SIBs) represents a grand technol. challenge to meet the continuously increased demand for the high-performance energy storage market. Here we report a facile and reliable synthetic strategy for in situ growth of few-layer MoS2 nanosheets on reduced graphene oxide (rGO) cross-linked hollow carbon spheres (HCS) with formation of three-dimensional (3D) network nanohybrids (MoS2-rGO/HCS). Systematic electrochem. studies demonstrate, as an anode of LIBs, the as-developed MoS2-rGO/HCS can deliver a reversible capacity of 1145 mAh g-1 after 100 cycles at 0.1 A g-1 and a revisible capacity of 753 mAh g-1 over 1000 cycles at 2 A g-1. For SIBs, the as-developed MoS2-rGO/HCS can also maintain a reversible capacity of 443 mAh g-1 at 1 A g-1 after 500 cycles. The excellent electrochem. performance can be attributed to the 3D porous structures, in which the few-layer MoS2 nanosheets with expanded interlayers can provide shortened ion diffusion paths and improved Li+/Na+ diffusion mobility, and the hollow porous carbon spheres and the outside graphene network are able to improve the cond. and maintain the structural integrity.

Hydrogen prodn. through water splitting has been considered as a green, pure and high-efficient technique. As an important half-reaction involved, hydrogen evolution reaction is a complex electrochem. process involving liq.-solid-gas three-phase interface behavior. Therefore, new concepts and strategies of material design are needed to smooth each pivotal step. Here we report a multiscale structural and electronic control of molybdenum disulfide foam to synergistically promote the hydrogen evolution process. The optimized three-dimensional molybdenum disulfide foam with uniform mesopores, vertically aligned two-dimensional layers and cobalt atoms doping demonstrated a high hydrogen evolution activity and stability. In addn., d. functional theory calcns. indicate that molybdenum disulfide with moderate cobalt doping content possesses the optimal activity. This study demonstrates the validity of multiscale control in molybdenum disulfide via overall consideration of the mass transport, and the accessibility, quantity and capability of active sites towards electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution, which may also be extended to other energy-related processes.

Emulsions stabilised solely by colloidal particles
Aveyard, Robert; Binks, Bernard P.; Clint, John H.

A review. The prepn. and properties of emulsions, stabilized solely by the adsorption of solid particles at the oil-H2O interface, are reviewed esp. in the light of our own work with particles of well-controlled surface properties. Where appropriate, comparison is made with the behavior of surfactant-stabilized emulsions. Hydrophilic particles tend to form oil-in-H2O (o/w) emulsions whereas hydrophobic particles form H2O-in-oil (w/o) emulsions. Many of the properties can be attributed to the very large free energy of adsorption for particles of intermediate wettability (contact angle at the oil-H2O interface, for example, between 50 and 130Â°). This effectively irreversible adsorption leads to extreme stability for certain emulsions and is in contrast to the behavior of surfactant mols. which are usually in rapid dynamic equil. between the oil-H2O interface and the bulk phases. There is evidence that, in some systems, weak flocculation of the particles improves the emulsion stability. Phase inversion from w/o to o/w can be brought about by increasing the vol. fraction of H2O. Emulsions close to this inversion point tend to be the most stable, again in contrast to surfactant systems. The vol. fraction needed for inversion depends on the particle wettability and the nature of the oil and these effects were rationalized in terms of surface energy components. Stable multiple emulsions (w/o/w and o/w/o) can be made using 2 types of particles with slightly different wettability. Similar multiple emulsions prepd. with 2 types of surfactant tend to be much less stable. The possibility of prepg. novel solid materials by evapg. solid-stabilized emulsions is also proposed. Finally the authors report on some extensions to the work of Levine et al. who obtained expressions for the free energy of formation of emulsion drops covered with close-packed monolayers of monodisperse spherical particles. In particular in the light of the observations that nanoparticles can act as excellent emulsion stabilizers, the authors have considered potential effects on the free energy of emulsion formation of the action of small (phys. realistic) pos. and neg. line tensions in the 3-phase contact lines skirting particles adsorbed at the droplet interfaces. The authors also explore the possibility that curvature properties of close-packed particle monolayers can affect emulsion properties in much the same way that surfactant monolayer properties influence emulsion type and stability.

Lithiation-exfoliation produces single to few-layered MoS2 and WS2 sheets dispersible in water. However, the process transforms them from the pristine semiconducting 2H phase to a distorted metallic phase. Recovery of the semiconducting properties typically involves heating of the chem. exfoliated sheets at elevated temps. Therefore, it was largely limited to sheets deposited on solid substrates. Here, we report the dispersion of chem. exfoliated MoS2 sheets in high b.p. org. solvents enabled by surface functionalization and the controllable recovery of their semiconducting properties directly in soln. This process connects the scalability of chem. exfoliation with the simplicity of soln. processing, ultimately enabling a facile method for tuning the metal to semiconductor transitions of MoS2 and WS2 within a liq. medium.

Tailoring the surface of nanoparticles is essential for biol. applications of magnetic nanoparticles. FePt nanoparticles are interesting candidates owing to their high magnetic moment. Established procedures to make FePt nanoparticles use oleic acid and oleylamine as the surfactants, which make them dispersed in nonpolar solvents such as hexane. As a model study to demonstrate the modification of the surface chem., stable aq. dispersions of FePt nanoparticles were synthesized after ligand exchange with mercaptoalkanoic acids. This report focuses on understanding the surface chem. of FePt upon ligand exchange with mercapto compds. by conducting XPS and Fourier transform IR spectroscopy (FTIR) studies. It was found that the mercapto end displaces oleylamine on the Pt atoms and the carboxylic acid end displaces the oleic acid on the Fe atoms, thus exposing carboxylate and thiolate groups on the surface that provide the necessary electrostatic repulsion to form stable aq. dispersions of FePt nanoparticles.

MoS2 are two-dimensional (2D) materials that exhibit emerging photoluminescence (PL) at the monolayer level and have potential optoelectronic applications. Monolayers of MoS2 typically achieved by mech. exfoliation (Me), chem. vapor deposition (CVD), and chem. exfoliation (Ce) via lithium intercalation contain numerous defects that significantly reduce their PL efficiency. Several studies have reported overcoming poor PL in mech. exfoliated and CVD-grown MoS2, but such studies for chem. exfoliated MoS2 (Ce-MoS2) have not been reported. Here, we report a soln.-based method of enhancing the PL of Ce-MoS2 by reacting with mols. with suitable functional groups at high temps. Reaction with dodecanethiol (DDT) generates PL that is more intense than mech. exfoliated MoS2 (Me-MoS2) with high crystallinity and has a significantly broader range of wavelengths. Based on UV-visible, Fourier transform IR, X-ray photoemission, and PL spectroscopy as well as transmission electron and PL imaging, we propose that the present method modifies PL properties of Ce-MoS2 by simultaneously annealing, replacing molybdenum-oxygen with molybdenum-sulfur bonds, inducing strain, and generating a nanopolycryst. structure. This work points to such defect engineering using mols. as an effective means to modify the properties of Ce-MoS2 and layered transition-metal dichalcogenides more generally.

The photocurrent conversions of transition metal dichalcogenide nanosheets are unprecedentedly impressive, making them great candidates for visible range photodetectors. Here we demonstrate a method for fabricating micron-thick, flexible films consisting of a variety of highly separated transition metal dichalcogenide nanosheets for excellent band-selective photodetection. Our method is based on the non-destructive modification of transition metal dichalcogenide sheets with amine-terminated polymers. The universal interaction between amine and transition metal resulted in scalable, stable and high concentration dispersions of a single to a few layers of numerous transition metal dichalcogenides. Our MoSe2 and MoS2 composites are highly photoconductive even at bending radii as low as 200 Î¼m on illumination of near infrared and visible light, respectively. More interestingly, simple solution mixing of MoSe2 and MoS2 gives rise to blended composite films in which the photodetection properties were controllable. The MoS2/MoSe2 (5:5) film showed broad range photodetection suitable for both visible and near infrared spectra.

The authors report the design of a novel microcapsule platform for in situ pH sensing and photothermal heating, which involves the encapsulation of pH-responsive polymer-coated molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) nanosheets (NSs) in microcapsules with an aq. core and a semipermeable polymeric shell. The MoS2 NSs were functionalized with pH-responsive polymers having fluorescent groups at the distal end to provide pH-sensitive Forster resonance energy transfer (FRET) effect. The pH-responsive polymers were carefully designed to produce a dramatic change in the polymer conformation, which translated to a change in the FRET efficiency near pH 7.0 in response to subtle pH changes, enabling the detection of cancer cells. The pH-sensitive MoS2 NSs were microfluidically encapsulated within semipermeable membranes to yield microcapsules with a uniform size and compn. The microcapsules retained the MoS2 NSs without leakage while allowing the diffusion of small ions and water through the membrane. At the same time, the membranes excluded adhesive proteins and lipids in the surrounding media, protecting the encapsulated MoS2 NSs from deactivation and enabling in situ pH monitoring. Moreover, the encapsulated MoS2 NSs showed high-performance photothermal heating, rendering the dual-functional microcapsules highly suitable for cancer diagnosis and treatment.

FePt nanoparticles coated with 2 nm thick films of surfactant were studied as candidates for magnetic recording media. The self-assembly of these nanoparticles is influenced by the properties of their surfaces which are coated with a layer of mixed oleic acid and oleyl amine. These surfactant coated FePt nanoparticles were characterized using FTIR spectroscopy. The observation of both Î½(COO) and Î½(C=O) vibrational modes indicates that oleic acid bonds to the FePt nanoparticles in both monodentate and bidentate forms. The oleylamine bonds to the FePt nanoparticles through electron donation from the nitrogen atom of the NH2 group. The FTIR spectra indicate that there is a conversion of the alkyl chains from the oleyl form (cis-9-octadecenyl) to the elaidyl form (trans-9-octadecenyl) during the synthesis of the FePt nanoparticles. This is revealed by the presence of several vibrational absorption bands in the region of the olefinic C-H stretching modes. The presence of elaidyl groups on the FePt surfaces is very important because the structures of the oleyl groups and the elaidyl groups are quite different and are expected to pack differently around the FePt nanoparticles. This in turn will influence the self-assembly of nanoparticles on substrates.

Gold nanoparticles (GNPs) are often used as colloidal carriers in numerous applications owing to their low-cost and size-controlled prepn. as well as their straightforward surface functionalization with thiol contg. mols. forming self-assembling monolayers (SAM). The quantification of the ligand d. of such modified GNPs is tech. challenging, yet of utmost importance for quality control in many applications. In this contribution, a new method for the detn. of the surface coverage of GNPs with thiol contg. ligands is proposed. It makes use of the measurement of the gold-to-sulfur (Au/S) ratio by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) and its dependence on the nanoparticle diam. The simultaneous ICP-MS measurement of gold and sulfur was carefully validated and found to be a robust method with a relative std. uncertainty of lower than 10%. A major advantage of this method is the independence from sample prepn.; for example, sample loss during the washing steps is not affecting the results. To demonstrate the utility of the straightforward method, GNPs of different diams. were synthesized and derivatized on the surface with bifunctional (lipophilic) Ï-mercapto-alkanoic acids and (hydrophilic) mercapto-poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG)n-carboxylic acids by self-assembling monolayer (SAM) formation. A size-independent but ligand-chain length-dependent ligand d. was found. The surface coverage increases from 4.3 to 6.3 mols. nm-2 with a decrease of ligand chain length from 3.52 to 0.68 nm. Furthermore, no significant difference between the surface coverage of hydrophilic and lipophilic ligands with approx. the same ligand length was found, indicating that steric hindrance is of more importance than, for example, intermol. strand interactions of Van der Waals forces as claimed in other studies.

A review. All nanomaterials share a common feature of large surface-to-vol. ratio, making their surfaces the dominant player in many phys. and chem. processes. Surface ligands - mols. that bind to the surface - are an essential component of nanomaterial synthesis, processing and application. Understanding the structure and properties of nanoscale interfaces requires an intricate mix of concepts and techniques borrowed from surface science and coordination chem. This Review elaborates these connections and discusses the bonding, electronic structure and chem. transformations at nanomaterial surfaces. The authors specifically focus on the role of surface ligands in tuning and rationally designing properties of functional nanomaterials. Given their importance for biomedical (imaging, diagnostics and therapeutics) and optoelectronic (light-emitting devices, transistors, solar cells) applications, the authors end with an assessment of application-targeted surface engineering.

MoS2 nanosheets have been used extensively in catalytic, electronic, optoelectronic and electrochem. research due to their diverse properties that are often detd. by the method of fabrication. Fine tuning of the colloidal behavior, specific interactions and further reactivity of the materials is typically achieved by subsequent surface modifications. Arguably the most permanent of these involve covalent attachment of mols. to either the molybdenum or the sulfur atoms in the lattice. Here we review of the nascent field of transition metal dichalcogenide (TMD) covalent functionalization and explore the prospective avenues for hybrid org.-inorg. nanomaterials.

Two-dimensional (2D) layered transition-metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) are a fascinating class of nanomaterials that have the potential for application in catalysis, electronics, photonics, energy storage, and sensing. TMDs are rather inert, and thus pose problems for chem. derivatization. However, to further modify the properties of TMDs and fully harness their capabilities, routes towards their chem. functionalization must be identified. Herein, recent efforts toward the chem. (bond-forming) functionalization of 2D TMDs are critically reviewed. Recent successes are highlighted, along with areas where further detailed analyses and experimentation are required. This burgeoning field is very much in its infancy but has already provided several important breakthroughs.

Surface-engineered, 10 nm-sized graphene quantum dots (GQDs) are shown to be efficient surfactants for producing 3-pentadecyl phenol (PDP)-combined poly(styrene-b-4-vinylpyridine) (PS-b-P4VP(PDP)) particles that feature tunable shapes and internal morphologies. The surface properties of GQDs were modified by grafting different alkyl ligands, such as hexylamine and oleylamine, to generate the surfactant behavior of the GQDs. In stark contrast to the behavior of the unmodified GQDs, hexylamine-grafted GQDs and oleylamine-grafted GQD surfactants were selectively positioned on the PS and P4VP(PDP) domains, resp., at the surface of the particles. This positioning effectively tuned the interfacial interaction between two different PS/P4VP(PDP) domains of the particles and the surrounding water during emulsification and induced a dramatic morphol. transition to convex lens-shaped particles. Precise and systematic control of interfacial activity of GQD surfactants was also demonstrated by varying the d. of the alkyl ligands on the GQDs. The excellent surface tunability of 10 nm-sized GQDs combined with their significant optical and elec. properties highlight their importance as surfactants for producing colloidal particles with novel functions.

Based on a recent report whereby we demonstrated the synthesis of polystyrene nanoparticles by miniemulsion polymn. stabilized by graphene oxide (GO) nanosheets as sole surfactant, we hereby report the synthesis of hybrid polymer nanoparticles of several members of the (meth)acrylate family and the cross-linker divinylbenzene via the same approach. The nature of the resultant emulsion is strongly linked to the polarity of the monomer used; monomers with a relatively small polar component (based on Hansen soly. parameters) such as lauryl methacrylate and benzyl methacrylate, in addn. to styrene, generate stable emulsions that can be effectively polymd. Particularly polar monomers (e.g., Me acrylate and Me methacrylate) formed kinetically stable emulsions in the presence of GO, however rapid coagulation occurred during polymn. Electron microscopy anal. reveals the formation of polymer nanoparticles with size distribution between 200 and 1000 nm with roughened surface morphologies, indicative of GO sheets adsorbed at the interface. The results of this work demonstrate the applicability of this synthetic route for specific monomers in the prepn. of novel graphene-based polymeric materials. Â© 2013 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J.
